an4.183:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
an4.183:4.2: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, a chief minister of Magadha, went up to the Buddha,
an4.183:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
an4.183:5.1: “Master Gotama, this is my doctrine and view:
an4.183:5.2: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve seen, saying:
an4.183:5.4: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve heard, saying:
an4.183:5.6: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve thought, saying:
an4.183:5.8: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve cognized, saying:
an4.183:6.1: “Brahmin, I don’t say you should talk about everything you see, hear, think, and cognize.
an4.183:6.2: But I also don’t say you should talk about nothing you see, hear, think, and cognize.
an4.183:7.1: When talking about certain things you’ve seen, heard, thought, or cognized, unwholesome qualities grow while wholesome qualities decline. I say that you shouldn’t talk about those things.
an4.183:7.2: When talking about other things you’ve seen, heard, thought, or cognized, unwholesome qualities decline while wholesome qualities grow. I say that you should talk about those things.”
an4.183:11.1: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.
